Verse: பொருட்பொருளார்	புன்னலந்	தோயார்	அருட்பொருள்			ஆயும்	அறிவி	னவர்.
Translation: Translation :Their worthless charms, whose only weal is wealth of gain, From touch of these the wise, who seek the wealth of grace, abstain.
Explanation: Explanation :The wise who seek the wealth of grace will not desire the base favours of those who regard wealth (and not pleasure) as (their) riches.

Verse: பொதுநலத்தார்	புன்னலம்	தோயார்	மதிநலத்தின்			மாண்ட	அறிவி	னவர்.
Translation: Translation :From contact with their worthless charms, whose charms to all are free, The men with sense of good and lofty wisdom blest will flee;
Explanation: Explanation :Those whose knowledge is made excellent by their (natural) sense will not covet the trffling delights of those whose favours are common (to all).

Verse: தந்நலம்	பார஧ப்பார்	தோயார்	தகைசெருக்கிப்			புன்னலம்	பாரிப்பார்	தோள்.
Translation: Translation :From touch of those who worthless charms, with wanton arts, display, The men who would their own true good maintain will turn away.
Explanation: Explanation :Those who would spread (the fame of) their own goodness will not desire the shoulders of those who rejoice in their accomplishments and bestow their despicable favours (on all who pay).

Verse: நிறைநெஞ்சம்	இல்லவர்	தோய்வார்	பிறநெஞ்சிற்			பேணிப்	புணர்பவர்	தோள்.
Translation: Translation :Who cherish alien thoughts while folding in their feigned embrace, These none approach save those devoid of virtue's grace.
Explanation: Explanation :Those who are destitute of a perfectly (reformed) mind will covet the shoulders of those who embrace (them) while their hearts covet other things.

Verse: ஆயும்	அறிவினர்	அல்லார்க்கு	அணங்கென்ப			மாய	மகளிர்	முயக்கு.
Translation: Translation :As demoness who lures to ruin woman's treacherous love To men devoid of wisdom's searching power will prove.
Explanation: Explanation :The wise say that to such as are destitute of discerning sense the embraces of faithless women are (as ruinous as those of) the celestail female.

Verse: வரைவிலா	மாணிழையார்	மென்தோள்	புரையிலாப்			பூரியர்கள்	ஆழும்	அளறு.
Translation: Translation :The wanton's tender arm, with gleaming jewels decked, Is hell, where sink degraded souls of men abject.
Explanation: Explanation :The delicate shoulders of prostitutes with excellent jewels are a hell into which are plunged the ignorant base.

Verse: இருமனப்	பெண்டிரும்	கள்ளும்	கவறும்			திருநீக்கப்	பட்டார்	தொடர்பு.
Translation: Translation :Women of double minds, strong drink, and dice; to these giv'n o'er, Are those on whom the light of Fortune shines no more.
Explanation: Explanation :Treacherous women, liquor, and gambling are the associates of such as have forsaken by Fortune.

Verse: உட்கப்	படாஅர்	ஒளியிழப்பர்	எஞ்ஞான்றும்			கட்காதல்	கொண்டொழுகு	வார்.
Translation: Translation :Who love the palm's intoxicating juice, each day, No rev'rence they command, their glory fades away.
Explanation: Explanation :Those who always thirst after drink will neither inspire fear (in others) nor retain the light (of their fame).

Verse: உண்ணற்க	கள்ளை	உணில்உண்க	சான்றோரான்			எண்ணப்	படவேண்டா	தார்.
Translation: Translation :Drink not inebriating draught. Let him count well the cost. Who drinks, by drinking, all good men's esteem is lost.
Explanation: Explanation :Let no liquor be drunk; if it is desired, let it be drunk by those who care not for esteem of the great.

Verse: ஈன்றாள்	முகத்தேயும்	இன்னாதால்	என்மற்றுச்			சான்றோர்	முகத்துக்	களி.
Translation: Translation :The drunkard's joy is sorrow to his mother's eyes; What must it be in presence of the truly wise?
Explanation: Explanation :Intoxication is painful even in the presence of (one's) mother; what will it not then be in that of the wise ?

Verse: நாண்என்னும்	நல்லாள்	புறங்கொடுக்கும்	கள்ளென்னும்			பேணாப்	பெருங்குற்றத்	தார்க்கு.
Translation: Translation :Shame, goodly maid, will turn her back for aye on them Who sin the drunkard's grievous sin, that all condemn.
Explanation: Explanation :The fair maid of modesty will turn her back on those who are guilty of the great and abominable crime of drunkenness.

Verse: கையறி	யாமை	உடைத்தே	பொருள்கொடுத்து			மெய்யறி	யாமை	கொளல்.
Translation: Translation :With gift of goods who self-oblivion buys, Is ignorant of all that man should prize.
Explanation: Explanation :To give money and purchase unconsciousness is the result of one's ignorance of (one's own actions).

Verse: துஞ்சினார்	செத்தாரின்	வேறல்லர்	எஞ்ஞான்றும்			நஞ்சுண்பார்	கள்ளுண்	பவர்.
Translation: Translation :Sleepers are as the dead, no otherwise they seem; Who drink intoxicating draughts, they poison quaff, we deem.
Explanation: Explanation :They that sleep resemble the deed; (likewise) they that drink are no other than poison-eaters.

Verse: உள்ளொற்றி	உள்ளூர்	நகப்படுவர்	எஞ்ஞான்றும்			கள்ளொற்றிக்	கண்சாய்	பவர்3
Translation: Translation :Who turn aside to drink, and droop their heavy eye, Shall be their townsmen's jest, when they the fault espy.
Explanation: Explanation :Those who always intoxicate themselves by a private (indulgence in) drink; will have their secrets detected and laughed at by their fellow-townsmen.

Verse: களித்தறியேன்	என்பது	கைவிடுக	நெஞ்சத்து			ஒளித்ததூஉம்	ஆங்கே	மிகும்.
Translation: Translation :No more in secret drink, and then deny thy hidden fraud; What in thy mind lies hid shall soon be known abroad.
Explanation: Explanation :Let (the drunkard) give up saying "I have never drunk"; (for) the moment (he drinks) he will simply betray his former attempt to conceal.

Verse: களித்தானைக்	காரணம்	காட்டுதல்	கீழ்நீர்க்			குளித்தானைத்	தீத்துரீஇ	அற்று.
Translation: Translation :Like him who, lamp in hand, would seek one sunk beneath the wave. Is he who strives to sober drunken man with reasonings grave.
Explanation: Explanation :Reasoning with a drunkard is like going under water with a torch in search of a drowned man.

Verse: கள்ளுண்ணாப்	போழ்திற்	களித்தானைக்	காணுங்கால்			உள்ளான்கொல்	உண்டதன்	சோர்வு.
Translation: Translation :When one, in sober interval, a drunken man espies, Does he not think, 'Such is my folly in my revelries'?
Explanation: Explanation :When (a drunkard) who is sober sees one who is not, it looks as if he remembered not the evil effects of his (own) drink.

Verse: வேண்டற்க	வென்றிடினும்	சூதினை	வென்றதூஉம்			தூண்டிற்பொன்	மீன்விழுங்கி	அற்று.
Translation: Translation :Seek not the gamester's play; though you should win, Your gain is as the baited hook the fish takes in.
Explanation: Explanation :Though able to win, let not one desire gambling; (for) even what is won is like a fish swallowing the iron in fish-hook.

Verse: ஒன்றெய்தி	நூறிழக்கும்	சூதர்க்கும்	உண்டாங்கொல்			நன்றெய்தி	வாழ்வதோர்	ஆறு.
Translation: Translation :Is there for gamblers, too, that gaining one a hundred lose, some way That they may good obtain, and see a prosperous day?
Explanation: Explanation :Is there indeed a means of livelihood that can bestow happiness on gamblers who gain one and lose a hundred ?

Verse: உருளாயம்	ஓவாது	கூறின்	பொருளாயம்			போஒய்ப்	புறமே	படும்.
Translation: Translation :If prince unceasing speak of nought but play, Treasure and revenue will pass from him away.
Explanation: Explanation :If the king is incessantly addicted to the rolling dice in the hope of gain, his wealth and the resources thereof will take their departure and fall into other's hands.

Verse: சிறுமை	பலசெய்து	சீரழ஧க்கும்	சூதின்			வறுமை	தருவதொன்று	இல்.
Translation: Translation :Gaming brings many woes, and ruins fair renown; Nothing to want brings men so surely down.
Explanation: Explanation :There is nothing else that brings (us) poverty like gambling which causes many a misery and destroys (one's) reputation.

Verse: கவறும்	கழகமும்	கையும்	தருக்கி			இவறியார்	இல்லாகி	யார்.
Translation: Translation :The dice, and gaming-hall, and gamester's art, they eager sought, Thirsting for gain- the men in other days who came to nought.
Explanation: Explanation :Penniless are those who by reason of their attachment would never forsake gambling, the gambling-place and the handling (of dice).

Verse: அகடாரார்	அல்லல்	உழப்பர்சூ	தென்னும்			முகடியான்	மூடப்பட்	டார்.
Translation: Translation :Gambling's Misfortune's other name: o'er whom she casts her veil, They suffer grievous want, and sorrows sore bewail.
Explanation: Explanation :Those who are swallowed by the goddess called "gambling" will never have their hunger satisfied, but suffer the pangs of hell in the next world.

Verse: பழகிய	செல்வமும்	பண்பும்	கெடுக்கும்			கழகத்துக்	காலை	புகின்.
Translation: Translation :Ancestral wealth and noble fame to ruin haste, If men in gambler's halls their precious moments waste.
Explanation: Explanation :To waste time at the place of gambling will destroy inherited wealth and goodness of character.

Verse: பொருள்கெடுத்துப்	பொய்மேற்	கொளீஇ	அருள்கெடுத்து			அல்லல்	உழப்பிக்கும்	சூது.
Translation: Translation :Gambling wastes wealth, to falsehood bends the soul: it drives away All grace, and leaves the man to utter misery a prey.
Explanation: Explanation :Gambling destroys property, teaches falsehood, puts an end to benevolence, and brings in misery (here and hereafter).

Verse: உடைசெல்வம்	ஊண்ஒளி	கல்விஎன்று	ஐந்தும்			அடையாவாம்	ஆயங்	கொளின்.
Translation: Translation :Clothes, wealth, food, praise, and learning, all depart From him on gambler's gain who sets his heart.
Explanation: Explanation :The habit of gambling prevents the attainment of these five: clothing, wealth, food, fame and learning.

Verse: இழத்தொறூஉம்	காதலிக்கும்	சூதேபோல்	துன்பம்			உழத்தொறூஉம்	காதற்று	உயிர்.
Translation: Translation :Howe'er he lose, the gambler's heart is ever in the play; E'en so the soul, despite its griefs, would live on earth alway.
Explanation: Explanation :As the gambler loves (his vice) the more he loses by it, so does the soul love (the body) the more it suffers through it.

Verse: மிகினும்	குறையினும்	நோய்செய்யும்	நூலோர்			வளிமுதலா	எண்ணிய	மூன்று.
Translation: Translation :The learned books count three, with wind as first; of these, As any one prevail, or fail; 'twill cause disease.
Explanation: Explanation :If (food and work are either) excessive or deficient, the three things enumerated by (medical) writers, flatulence, biliousness, and phlegm, will cause (one) disease.

Verse: மருந்தென	வேண்டாவாம்	யாக்கைக்கு	அருந்தியது			அற்றது	போற்றி	உணின்.
Translation: Translation :No need of medicine to heal your body's pain, If, what you ate before digested well, you eat again.
Explanation: Explanation :No medicine is necessary for him who eats after assuring (himself) that what he has (already) eaten has been digested.

Verse: அற்றால்	அறவறிந்து	உண்க	அஃதுடம்பு			பெற்றான்	நெடிதுய்க்கும்	ஆறு.
Translation: Translation :Who has a body gained may long the gift retain, If, food digested well, in measure due he eat again.
Explanation: Explanation :If (one's food has been) digested let one eat with moderation; (for) that is the way to prolong the life of an embodied soul.

Verse: அற்றது	அறிந்து	கடைப்பிடித்து	மாறல்ல			துய்க்க	துவரப்	பசித்து.
Translation: Translation :Knowing the food digested well, when hunger prompteth thee, With constant care, the viands choose that well agree.
Explanation: Explanation :(First) assure yourself that your food has been digested and never fail to eat, when very hungry, whatever is not disagreeable (to you).

Verse: மாறுபாடு	இல்லாத	உண்டி	மறுத்துண்ணின்			ஊறுபாடு	இல்லை	உயிர்க்கு.
Translation: Translation :With self-denial take the well-selected meal; So shall thy frame no sudden sickness feel.
Explanation: Explanation :There will be no disaster to one's life if one eats with moderation, food that is not disagreeable.

Verse: இழிவறிந்து	உண்பான்கண்	இன்பம்போல்	நிற்கும்			கழிபேர்	இரையான்கண்	நோய்.
Translation: Translation :On modest temperance as pleasures pure, So pain attends the greedy epicure.
Explanation: Explanation :As pleasure dwells with him who eats moderately, so disease (dwells) with the glutton who eats voraciously.

Verse: தீயள	வன்றித்	தெரியான்	பெரிதுண்ணின்			நோயள	வின்றிப்	படும்.
Translation: Translation :Who largely feeds, nor measure of the fire within maintains, That thoughtless man shall feel unmeasured pains.
Explanation: Explanation :He will be afflicted with numberless diseases, who eats immoderately, ignorant (of the rules of health).

Verse: நோய்நாடி	நோய்முதல்	நாடி	அதுதணிக்கும்			வாய்நாடி	வாய்ப்பச்	செயல்.
Translation: Translation :Disease, its cause, what may abate the ill: Let leech examine these, then use his skill.
Explanation: Explanation :Let the physician enquire into the (nature of the) disease, its cause and its method of cure and treat it faithfully according to (medical rule).

Verse: உற்றான்	அளவும்	பிணியளவும்	காலமும்			கற்றான்	கருதிச்	செயல்.
Translation: Translation :The habitudes of patient and disease, the crises of the ill These must the learned leech think over well, then use his skill.
Explanation: Explanation :The learned (physician) should ascertain the condition of his patient; the nature of his disease, and the season (of the year) and (then) proceed (with his treatment).

Verse: உற்றவன்	தீர்ப்பான்	மருந்துழைச்	செல்வானென்று			அப்பால்	நாற்கூற்றே	மருந்து.
Translation: Translation :For patient, leech, and remedies, and him who waits by patient's side, The art of medicine must fourfold code of laws provide.
Explanation: Explanation :Medical science consists of four parts, viz., patient, physician, medicine and compounder; and each of these (again) contains four sub-divisions.

Verse: இற்பிறந்தார்	கண்அல்லது	இல்லை	இயல்பாகச்			செப்பமும்	நாணும்	ஒருங்கு.
Translation: Translation :Save in the scions of a noble house, you never find Instinctive sense of right and virtuous shame combined.
Explanation: Explanation :Consistency (of thought, word and deed) and fear (of sin) are conjointly natural only to the high-born.

Verse: ஒழுக்கமும்	வாய்மையும்	நாணும்இம்	மூன்றும்			இழுக்கார்	குடிப்பிறந்	தார்.
Translation: Translation :In these three things the men of noble birth fail not: In virtuous deed and truthful word, and chastened thought.
Explanation: Explanation :The high-born will never deviate from these three; good manners, truthfulness and modesty.

Verse: நகைஈகை	இன்சொல்	இகழாமை	நான்கும்			வகையென்ப	வாய்மைக்	குடிக்கு.
Translation: Translation :The smile, the gift, the pleasant word, unfailing courtesy These are the signs, they say, of true nobility.
Explanation: Explanation :A cheerful countenance, liberality, pleasant words, and an unreviling disposition, these four are said to be the proper qualities of the truly high-born.

Verse: அடுக்கிய	கோடி	பெறினும்	குடிப்பிறந்தார்			குன்றுவ	செய்தல்	இலர்.
Translation: Translation :Millions on millions piled would never win The men of noble race to soul-degrading sin.
Explanation: Explanation :Though blessed with immense wealth, the noble will never do anything unbecoming.

Verse: வழங்குவ	துள்வீழ்ந்தக்	கண்ணும்	பழங்குடி			பண்பில்	தலைப்பிரிதல்	இன்று.
Translation: Translation :Though stores for charity should fail within, the ancient race Will never lose its old ancestral grace.
Explanation: Explanation :Though their means fall off, those born in ancient families, will not lose their character (for liberality).

Verse: சலம்பற்றிச்	சால்பில	செய்யார்மா	சற்ற			குலம்பற்றி	வாழ்தும்என்	பார்.
Translation: Translation :Whose minds are set to live as fits their sire's unspotted fame, Stooping to low deceit, commit no deeds that gender shame.
Explanation: Explanation :Those who seek to preserve the irreproachable honour of their families will not viciously do what is detrimental thereto.

Verse: குடிப்பிறந்தார்	கண்விளங்கும்	குற்றம்	விசும்பின்			மதிக்கண்	மறுப்போல்	உயர்ந்து.
Translation: Translation :The faults of men of noble race are seen by every eye, As spots on her bright orb that walks sublime the evening sky.
Explanation: Explanation :The defects of the noble will be observed as clearly as the dark spots in the moon.

Verse: நலத்தின்கண்	நாரின்மை	தோன்றின்	அவனைக்			குலத்தின்கண்	ஐயப்	படும்.
Translation: Translation :If lack of love appear in those who bear some goodly name, 'Twill make men doubt the ancestry they claim.
Explanation: Explanation :If one of a good family betrays want of affection, his descent from it will be called in question.

Verse: நிலத்தில்	கிடந்தமை	கால்காட்டும்	காட்டும்			குலத்தில்	பிறந்தார்வாய்ச்	சொல்.
Translation: Translation :Of soil the plants that spring thereout will show the worth: The words they speak declare the men of noble birth.
Explanation: Explanation :As the sprout indicates the nature of the soil, (so) the speech of the noble indicates (that of one's birth).

Verse: நலம்வேண்டின்	நாணுடைமை	வேண்டும்	குலம்			வேண்டின்	வேண்டுக	யார்க்கும்	பணிவு.
Translation: Translation :Who seek for good the grace of virtuous shame must know; Who seek for noble name to all must reverence show.
Explanation: Explanation :He who desires a good name must desire modesty; and he who desires (the continuance of) a family greatness must be submissive to all.

Verse: இன்றி	அமையாச்	சிறப்பின	ஆயினும்			குன்ற	வருப	விடல்.
Translation: Translation :Though linked to splendours man no otherwise may gain, Reject each act that may thine honour's clearness stain.
Explanation: Explanation :Actions that would degrade (one's) family should not be done; though they may be so important that not doing them would end in death.

Verse: சீரினும்	சீரல்ல	செய்யாரே	சீரொடு			பேராண்மை	வேண்டு	பவர்.
Translation: Translation :Who seek with glory to combine honour's untarnished fame, Do no inglorious deeds, though men accord them glory's name.
Explanation: Explanation :Those who desire (to maintain their) honour, will surely do nothing dishonourable, even for the sake of fame.

Verse: பெருக்கத்து	வேண்டும்	பணிதல்	சிறிய			சுருக்கத்து	வேண்டும்	உயர்வு.
Translation: Translation :Bow down thy soul, with increase blest, in happy hour; Lift up thy heart, when stript of all by fortune's power.
Explanation: Explanation :In great prosperity humility is becoming; dignity, in great adversity.

Verse: தலையின்	இழிந்த	மயிரனையர்	மாந்தர்			நிலையின்	இழிந்தக்	கடை.
Translation: Translation :Like hairs from off the head that fall to earth, When fall'n from high estate are men of noble birth.
Explanation: Explanation :They who have fallen from their (high) position are like the hair which has fallen from the head.

Verse: குன்றின்	அனையாரும்	குன்றுவர்	குன்றுவ			குன்றி	அனைய	செயின்.
Translation: Translation :If meanness, slight as 'abrus' grain, by men be wrought, Though like a hill their high estate, they sink to nought.
Explanation: Explanation :Even those who are exalted like a hill will be thought low, if they commit deeds that are debasing.

Verse: புகழ்இன்றால்	புத்தேள்நாட்டு	உய்யாதால்	என்மற்று			இகழ்வார்பின்	சென்று	நிலை.
Translation: Translation :It yields no praise, nor to the land of Gods throws wide the gate: Why follow men who scorn, and at their bidding wait?
Explanation: Explanation :Of what good is it (for the high-born) to go and stand in vain before those who revile him ? it only brings him loss of honour and exclusion from heaven.

Verse: ஒட்டார்பின்	சென்றொருவன்	வாழ்தலின்	அந்நிலையே			கெட்டான்	எனப்படுதல்	நன்று.
Translation: Translation :Better 'twere said, 'He's perished!' than to gain The means to live, following in foeman's train.
Explanation: Explanation :It is better for a man to be said of him that he died in his usual state than that he eked out his life by following those who disgraced him.

Verse: மருந்தோமற்று	ஊன்ஓம்பும்	வாழ்க்கை	பெருந்தகைமை			பீடழிய	வந்த	இடத்து.
Translation: Translation :When high estate has lost its pride of honour meet, Is life, that nurses this poor flesh, as nectar sweet?
Explanation: Explanation :For the high-born to keep their body in life when their honour is gone will certainly not prove a remedy against death.

Verse: மயிர்நீப்பின்	வாழாக்	கவரிமா	அன்னார்			உயிர்நீப்பர்	மானம்	வரின்.
Translation: Translation :Like the wild ox that, of its tuft bereft, will pine away, Are those who, of their honour shorn, will quit the light of day.
Explanation: Explanation :Those who give up (their) life when (their) honour is at stake are like the yark which kills itself at the loss of (even one of) its hairs.

Verse: இளிவரின்	வாழாத	மானம்	உடையார்			ஒளிதொழுது	ஏத்தும்	உலகு.
Translation: Translation :Who, when dishonour comes, refuse to live, their honoured memory Will live in worship and applause of all the world for aye!
Explanation: Explanation :The world will (always) praise and adore the fame of the honourable who would rather die than suffer indignity.

Verse: ஒளிஒருவற்கு	உள்ள	வெறுக்கை	இளிஒருவற்கு			அஃதிறந்து	வாழ்தும்	எனல்.
Translation: Translation :The light of life is mental energy; disgrace is his Who says, 'I 'ill lead a happy life devoid of this.'
Explanation: Explanation :One's light is the abundance of one's courage; one's darkness is the desire to live destitute of such (a state of mind.)

Verse: பிறப்பொக்கும்	எல்லா	உயிர்க்கும்	சிறப்பொவ்வா			செய்தொழில்	வேற்றுமை	யான்.
Translation: Translation :All men that live are one in circumstances of birth; Diversities of works give each his special worth.
Explanation: Explanation :All human beings agree as regards their birth but differ as regards their characteristics, because of the different qualities of their actions.

Verse: மேலிருந்தும்	மேலல்லார்	மேலல்லர்	கீழிருந்தும்			கீழல்லார்	கீழல்	லவர்.
Translation: Translation :The men of lofty line, whose souls are mean, are never great The men of lowly birth, when high of soul, are not of low estate.
Explanation: Explanation :Though (raised) above, the base cannot become great; though (brought) low, the great cannot become base.

Verse: ஒருமை	மகளிரே	போலப்	பெருமையும்			தன்னைத்தான்	கொண்டொழுகின்	உண்டு.
Translation: Translation :Like single-hearted women, greatness too, Exists while to itself is true.
Explanation: Explanation :Even greatness, like a woman's chastity, belongs only to him who guards himself.

Verse: பெருமை	யுடையவர்	ஆற்றுவார்	ஆற்றின்			அருமை	உடைய	செயல்.
Translation: Translation :The man endowed with greatness true, Rare deeds in perfect wise will do.
Explanation: Explanation :(Though reduced) the great will be able to perform, in the proper way, deeds difficult (for others to do).

Verse: சிறியார்	உணர்ச்சியுள்	இல்லை	பெரியாரைப்			பேணிக்	கொள்	வேம்	என்னும்			நோக்கு.
Translation: Translation :'As votaries of the truly great we will ourselves enroll,' Is thought that enters not the mind of men of little soul.
Explanation: Explanation :It is never in the nature of the base to seek the society of the great and partake of their nature.

Verse: இறப்பே	புரிந்த	தொழிற்றாம்	சிறப்புந்தான்			சீரல்	லவர்கண்	படின்.
Translation: Translation :Whene'er distinction lights on some unworthy head, Then deeds of haughty insolence are bred.
Explanation: Explanation :Even nobility of birth, wealth and learning, if in (the possession of) the base, will (only) produce everincreasing pride.

Verse: பணியுமாம்	என்றும்	பெருமை	சிறுமை			அணியுமாம்	தன்னை	வியந்து.
Translation: Translation :Greatness humbly bends, but littleness always Spreads out its plumes, and loads itself with praise.
Explanation: Explanation :The great will always humble himself; but the mean will exalt himself in self-admiration.

Verse: பெருமை	பெருமிதம்	இன்மை	சிறுமை			பெருமிதம்	ஊர்ந்து	விடல்.
Translation: Translation :Greatness is absence of conceit; meanness, we deem, Riding on car of vanity supreme.
Explanation: Explanation :Freedom from conceit is (the nature of true) greatness; (while) obstinacy therein is (that of) meanness.

Verse: அற்றம்	மறைக்கும்	பெருமை	சிறுமைதான்			குற்றமே	கூறி	விடும்.
Translation: Translation :Greatness will hide a neighbour's shame; Meanness his faults to all the world proclaim.
Explanation: Explanation :The great hide the faults of others; the base only divulge them.

Verse: கடன்என்ப	நல்லவை	எல்லாம்	கடன்அறிந்து			சான்றாண்மை	மேற்கொள்	பவர்க்கு.
Translation: Translation :All goodly things are duties to the men, they say Who set themselves to walk in virtue's perfect way.
Explanation: Explanation :It is said that those who are conscious of their duty and behave with a perfect goodness will regard as natural all that is good.

Verse: குணநலம்	சான்றோர்	நலனே	பிறநலம்			எந்நலத்து	உள்ளதூஉம்	அன்று.
Translation: Translation :The good of inward excellence they claim, The perfect men; all other good is only good in name.
Explanation: Explanation :The only delight of the perfect is that of their goodness; all other (sensual) delights are not to be included among any (true) delights.

Verse: அன்புநாண்	ஒப்புரவு	கண்ணோட்டம்	வாய்மையொடு			ஐந்துசால்	ஊன்றிய	தூண்.
Translation: Translation :Love, modesty, beneficence, benignant grace, With truth, are pillars five of perfect virtue's resting-place.
Explanation: Explanation :Affection, fear (of sin), benevolence, favour and truthfulness; these are the five pillars on which perfect goodness rests.

Verse: கொல்லா	நலத்தது	நோன்மை	பிறர்தீமை			சொல்லா	நலத்தது	சால்பு.
Translation: Translation :The type of 'penitence' is virtuous good that nothing slays; To speak no ill of other men is perfect virtue's praise.
Explanation: Explanation :Penance consists in the goodness that kills not , and perfection in the goodness that tells not others' faults.

Verse: ஆற்றுவார்	ஆற்றல்	பணிதல்	அதுசான்றோர்			மாற்றாரை	மாற்றும்	படை.
Translation: Translation :Submission is the might of men of mighty acts; the sage With that same weapon stills his foeman's rage.
Explanation: Explanation :Stooping (to inferiors) is the strength of those who can accomplish (an undertaking); and that is the weapon with which the great avert their foes.

Verse: சால்பிற்குக்	கட்டளை	யாதெனின்	தோல்வி			துலையல்லார்	கண்ணும்	கொளல்.
Translation: Translation :What is perfection's test? The equal mind. To bear repulse from even meaner men resigned.
Explanation: Explanation :The touch-stone of perfection is to receive a defeat even at the hands of one's inferiors.

Verse: இன்னாசெய்	தார்க்கும்	இனியவே	செய்யாக்கால்			என்ன	பயத்ததோ	சால்பு.
Translation: Translation :What fruit doth your perfection yield you, say! Unless to men who work you ill good repay?
Explanation: Explanation :Of what avail is perfect goodness if it cannot do pleasing things even to those who have pained (it) ?

Verse: இன்மை	ஒருவற்கு	இனிவன்று	சால்பென்னும்			திண்மைஉண்	டாகப்	பெறின்.
Translation: Translation :To soul with perfect virtue's strength endued, Brings no disgrace the lack of every earthly good.
Explanation: Explanation :Poverty is no disgrace to one who abounds in good qualities.

Verse: ஊழி	பெயரினும்	தாம்பெயரார்	சான்றாண்மைக்கு			ஆழி	எனப்படு	வார்.
Translation: Translation :Call them of perfect virtue's sea the shore, Who, though the fates should fail, fail not for evermore.
Explanation: Explanation :Those who are said to be the shore of the sea of perfection will never change, though ages may change.

Verse: சான்றவர்	சான்றாண்மை	குன்றின்	இருநிலந்தான்			தாங்காது	மன்னோ	பொறை.
Translation: Translation :The mighty earth its burthen to sustain must cease, If perfect virtue of the perfect men decrease.
Explanation: Explanation :If there is a defect in the character of the perfect, (even) the great world cannot bear (its) burden.

Verse: எண்பதத்தால்	எய்தல்	எளிதென்ப	யார்மாட்டும்			பண்புடைமை	என்னும்	வழக்கு.
Translation: Translation :Who easy access give to every man, they say, Of kindly courtesy will learn with ease the way.
Explanation: Explanation :If one is easy of access to all, it will be easy for one to obtain the virtue called goodness.

Verse: அன்புடைமை	ஆன்ற	குடிப்பிறத்தல்	இவ்விரண்டும்			பண்புடைமை	என்னும்	வழக்கு.
Translation: Translation :Benevolence and high born dignity, These two are beaten paths of courtesy.
Explanation: Explanation :Affectionateness and birth in a good family, these two constitute what is called a proper behaviour to all.

Verse: உறுப்பொத்தல்	மக்களொப்பு	அன்றால்	வெறுத்தக்க			பண்பொத்தல்	ஒப்பதாம்	ஒப்பு.
Translation: Translation :Men are not one because their members seem alike to outward view; Similitude of kindred quality makes likeness true.
Explanation: Explanation :Resemblance of bodies is no resemblance of souls; true resemblance is the resemblance of qualities that attract.

Verse: யனொடு	நன்றி	புரிந்த	பயனுடையார்			பண்புபா	ராட்டும்	உலகு.
Translation: Translation :Of men of fruitful life, who kindly benefits dispense, The world unites to praise the 'noble excellence.'
Explanation: Explanation :The world applauds the character of those whose usefulness results from their equity and charity.

Verse: நகையுள்ளும்	இன்னா	திகழ்ச்சி	பகையுள்ளும்			பண்புள	பாடறிவார்	மாட்டு.
Translation: Translation :Contempt is evil though in sport. They who man's nature know, E'en in their wrath, a courteous mind will show.
Explanation: Explanation :Reproach is painful to one even in sport; those (therefore) who know the nature of others exhibit (pleasing) qualities even when they are hated.

Verse: பண்புடையார்ப்	பட்டுண்டு	உலகம்	அதுஇன்றேல்			மண்புக்கு	மாய்வது	மன்.
Translation: Translation :The world abides; for 'worthy' men its weight sustain. Were it not so, 'twould fall to dust again.
Explanation: Explanation :The (way of the) world subsists by contact with the good; if not, it would bury itself in the earth and perish.

Verse: அரம்போலும்	கூர்மைய	ரேனும்	மரம்போல்வர்			மக்கட்பண்பு	இல்லா	தவர்.
Translation: Translation :Though sharp their wit as file, as blocks they must remain, Whose souls are void of 'courtesy humane'.
Explanation: Explanation :He who is destitute of (true) human qualities (only) resembles a tree, though he may possess the sharpness of a file.

Verse: நண்பாற்றார்	ஆகி	நயமில	செய்வார்க்கும்			பண்பாற்றார்	ஆதல்	கடை.
Translation: Translation :Though men with all unfriendly acts and wrongs assail, 'Tis uttermost disgrace in 'courtesy' to fail.
Explanation: Explanation :It is wrong (for the wise) not to exhibit (good) qualities even towards those who bearing no friendship (for them) do only what is hateful.

Verse: நகல்வல்லர்	அல்லார்க்கு	மாயிரு	ஞாலம்			பகலும்பாற்	பட்டன்று	இருள்.
Translation: Translation :To him who knows not how to smile in kindly mirth, Darkness in daytime broods o'er all the vast and mighty earth.
Explanation: Explanation :To those who cannot rejoice, the wide world is buried darkness even in (broad) day light.

Verse: பண்பிலான்	பெற்ற	பெருஞ்செல்வம்	நன்பால்			கலந்தீமை	யால்திரிந்	தற்று.
Translation: Translation :Like sweet milk soured because in filthy vessel poured, Is ample wealth in churlish man's unopened coffers stored.
Explanation: Explanation :The great wealth obtained by one who has no goodness will perish like pure milk spoilt by the impurity of the vessel.

Verse: வைத்தான்வாய்	சான்ற	பெரும்பொருள்	அஃதுண்ணான்			செத்தான்	செயக்கிடந்தது	இல்.
Translation: Translation :Who fills his house with ample store, enjoying none, Is dead. Nought with the useless heap is done.
Explanation: Explanation :He who does not enjoy the immense riches he has heaped up in his house, is (to be reckoned as) dead, (for) there is nothing achieved (by him).

Verse: பொருளானாம்	எல்லாமென்று	ஈயாது	இவறும்			மருளானாம்	மாணாப்	பிறப்பு
Translation: Translation :Who giving nought, opines from wealth all blessing springs, Degraded birth that doting miser's folly brings.
Explanation: Explanation :He who knows that wealth yields every pleasure and yet is so blind as to lead miserly life will be born a demon.

Verse: ஈட்டம்	இவறி	இசைவேண்டா	ஆடவர்			தோற்றம்	நிலக்குப்	பொறை.
Translation: Translation :Who lust to heap up wealth, but glory hold not dear, It burthens earth when on the stage of being they appear.
Explanation: Explanation :A burden to the earth are men bent on the acquisition of riches and not (true) fame.

Verse: எச்சமென்று	என்எண்ணுங்	கொல்லோ	ஒருவரால்			நச்சப்	படாஅ	தவன்.
Translation: Translation :Whom no one loves, when he shall pass away, What doth he look to leave behind, I pray?
Explanation: Explanation :What will the miser who is not liked (by any one) regard as his own (in the world to come) ?

Verse: கொடுப்பதூஉம்	துய்ப்பதூஉம்	இல்லார்க்கு	அடுக்கிய			கோடியுண்	டாயினும்	இல்.
Translation: Translation :Amid accumulated millions they are poor, Who nothing give and nought enjoy of all they store.
Explanation: Explanation :Those who neither give (to others) nor enjoy (their property) are (truly) destitute, though possessing immense riches.

Verse: ஏதம்	பெருஞ்செல்வம்	தான்துவ்வான்	தக்கார்க்கொன்று			ஈதல்	இயல்பிலா	தான்.
Translation: Translation :Their ample wealth is misery to men of churlish heart, Who nought themselves enjoy, and nought to worthy men impart.
Explanation: Explanation :He who enjoys not (his riches) nor relieves the wants of the worthy is a disease to his wealth.

Verse: அற்றார்க்கொன்று	ஆற்றாதான்	செல்வம்	மிகநலம்			பெற்றாள்	தமியள்மூத்	தற்று.
Translation: Translation :Like woman fair in lonelihood who aged grows, Is wealth of him on needy men who nought bestows.
Explanation: Explanation :The wealth of him who never bestows anything on the destitute is like a woman of beauty growing old without a husband.

Verse: நச்சப்	படாதவன்	செல்வம்	நடுவூருள்			நச்சு	மரம்பழுத்	தற்று.
Translation: Translation :When he whom no man loves exults in great prosperity, 'Tis as when fruits in midmost of the town some poisonous tree.
Explanation: Explanation :The wealth of him who is disliked (by all) is like the fruit-bearing of the etty tree in the midst of a town.

Verse: அன்பொரீஇத்	தற்செற்று	அறநோக்காது	ஈட்டிய			ஒண்பொருள்	கொள்வார்	பிறர்.
Translation: Translation :Who love abandon, self-afflict, and virtue's way forsake To heap up glittering wealth, their hoards shall others take.
Explanation: Explanation :Strangers will inherit the riches that have been acquired without regard for friendship, comfort and charity.

Verse: சீருடைச்	செல்வர்	சிறுதுனி	மாரி			வறங்கூர்ந்	தனையது	உடைத்து.
Translation: Translation :'Tis as when rain cloud in the heaven grows day, When generous wealthy man endures brief poverty.
Explanation: Explanation :The short-lived poverty of those who are noble and rich is like the clouds becoming poor (for a while).

Verse: கருமத்தால்	நாணுதல்	நாணுந்	திருநுதல்			நல்லவர்	நாணுப்	பிற.
Translation: Translation :To shrink abashed from evil deed is 'generous shame'; Other is that of bright-browed one of virtuous fame.
Explanation: Explanation :True modesty is the fear of (evil) deeds; all other modesty is (simply) the bashfulness of virtuous maids.

Verse: ஊணுடை	எச்சம்	உயிர்க்கெல்லாம்	வேறல்ல			நாணுடைமை	மாந்தர்	சிறப்பு.
Translation: Translation :Food, clothing, and other things alike all beings own; By sense of shame the excellence of men is known.
Explanation: Explanation :Food, clothing and the like are common to all men but modesty is peculiar to the good.

Verse: ஊனைக்	குறித்த	உயிரெல்லாம்	நாண்என்னும்			நன்மை	குறித்தது	சால்பு.
Translation: Translation :All spirits homes of flesh as habitation claim, And perfect virtue ever dwells with shame.
Explanation: Explanation :As the body is the abode of the spirit, so the excellence of modesty is the abode of perfection.

Verse: அணிஅன்றோ	நாணுடைமை	சான்றோர்க்கு	அஃதின்றேல்			பிணிஅன்றோ	பீடு	நடை.
Translation: Translation :And is not shame an ornament to men of dignity? Without it step of stately pride is piteous thing to see.
Explanation: Explanation :Is not the modesty ornament of the noble ? Without it, their haughtiness would be a pain (to others).

Verse: பிறர்பழியும்	தம்பழியும்	நாணுவார்	நாணுக்கு			உறைபதி	என்னும்	உலகு.
Translation: Translation :As home of virtuous shame by all the world the men are known, Who feel ashamed for others, guilt as for their own.
Explanation: Explanation :The world regards as the abode of modesty him who fear his own and other's guilt.

Verse: நாண்வேலி	கொள்ளாது	மன்னோ	வியன்ஞாலம்			பேணலர்	மேலா	யவர்.
Translation: Translation :Unless the hedge of shame inviolate remain, For men of lofty soul the earth's vast realms no charms retain.
Explanation: Explanation :The great make modesty their barrier (of defence) and not the wide world.

Verse: நாணால்	உயிரைத்	துறப்பர்	உயிர்ப்பொருட்டால்			நாண்துறவார்	நாணாள்	பவர்.
Translation: Translation :The men of modest soul for shame would life an offering make, But ne'er abandon virtuous shame for life's dear sake.
Explanation: Explanation :The modest would rather lose their life for the sake of modesty than lose modesty for the sake of life.

Verse: பிறர்நாணத்	தக்கது	தான்நாணா	னாயின்			அறம்நாணத்	தக்கது	உடைத்து.
Translation: Translation :Though know'st no shame, while all around asha med must be: Virtue will shrink away ashamed of thee!
Explanation: Explanation :Virtue is likely to forsake him who shamelessly does what others are ashamed of.

Verse: குலஞ்சுடும்	கொள்கை	பிழைப்பின்	நலஞ்சுடும்			நாணின்மை	நின்றக்	கடை.
Translation: Translation :'Twill race consume if right observance fail; 'Twill every good consume if shamelessness prevail.
Explanation: Explanation :Want of manners injures one's family; but want of modesty injures one's character.

Verse: நாண்அகத்	தில்லார்	இயக்கம்	மரப்பாவை			நாணால்	உயிர்மருட்டி	அற்று.
Translation: Translation :'Tis as with strings a wooden puppet apes life's functions, when Those void of shame within hold intercourse with men.
Explanation: Explanation :The actions of those who are without modesty at heart are like those of puppet moved by a string.

Verse: கருமம்	செயஒருவன்	கைதூவேன்	என்னும்			பெருமையின்	பீடுடையது	இல்.
Translation: Translation :Who says 'I'll do my work, nor slack my hand', His greatness, clothed with dignity supreme, shall stand.
Explanation: Explanation :There is no higher greatness than that of one saying. I will not cease in my effort (to raise my family).

Verse: ஆள்வினையும்	ஆன்ற	அறிவும்	எனஇரண்டின்			நீள்வினையால்	நீளும்	குடி.
Translation: Translation :The manly act and knowledge full, when these combine In deed prolonged, then lengthens out the race's line.
Explanation: Explanation :One's family is raised by untiring perseverance in both effort and wise contrivances.

Verse: குடிசெய்வல்	என்னும்	ஒருவற்குத்	தெய்வம்			மடிதற்றுத்	தான்முந்	துறும்.
Translation: Translation :'I'll make my race renowned,' if man shall say, With vest succinct the goddess leads the way.
Explanation: Explanation :The Deity will clothe itself and appear before him who resolves on raising his family.

Verse: சூழாமல்	தானே	முடிவெய்தும்	தம்குடியைத்			தாழாது	உஞற்று	பவர்க்கு.
Translation: Translation :Who labours for his race with unremitting pain, Without a thought spontaneously, his end will gain.
Explanation: Explanation :Those who are prompt in their efforts (to better their family) need no deliberation, such efforts will of themselves succeed.

Verse: குற்றம்	இலனாய்க்	குடிசெய்து	வாழ்வானைச்			சுற்றமாச்	சுற்றும்	உலகு.
Translation: Translation :With blameless life who seeks to build his race's fame, The world shall circle him, and kindred claim.
Explanation: Explanation :People will eagerly seek the friendship of the prosperous soul who has raised his family without foul means.

Verse: நல்லாண்மை	என்பது	ஒருவற்குத்	தான்பிறந்த			இல்லாண்மை	ஆக்கிக்	கொளல்.
Translation: Translation :Of virtuous manliness the world accords the praise To him who gives his powers, the house from which he sprang to raise.
Explanation: Explanation :A man's true manliness consists in making himself the head and benefactor of his family.

Verse: அமரகத்து	வன்கண்ணர்	போலத்	தமரகத்தும்			ஆற்றுவார்	மேற்றே	பொறை.
Translation: Translation :The fearless hero bears the brunt amid the warrior throng; Amid his kindred so the burthen rests upon the strong.
Explanation: Explanation :Like heroes in the battle-field, the burden (of protection etc.) is borne by those who are the most efficient in a family.

Verse: குடிசெய்வார்க்	கில்லை	பருவம்	மடிசெய்து			மானங்	கருதக்	கெடும்.
Translation: Translation :Wait for no season, when you would your house uprear; 'Twill perish, if you wait supine, or hold your honour dear.
Explanation: Explanation :As a family suffers by (one's) indolence and false dignity there is to be so season (good or bad) to those who strive to raise their family.

Verse: இடும்பைக்கே	கொள்கலம்	கொல்லோ	குடும்பத்தைக்			குற்ற	மறைப்பான்	உடம்பு.
Translation: Translation :Is not his body vase that various sorrows fill, Who would his household screen from every ill?
Explanation: Explanation :Is it only to suffering that his body is exposed who undertakes to preserve his family from evil ?

Verse: இடுக்கண்கால்	கொன்றிட	வீழும்	அடுத்தூன்றும்			நல்லாள்	இலாத	குடி.
Translation: Translation :When trouble the foundation saps the house must fall, If no strong hand be nigh to prop the tottering wall.
Explanation: Explanation :If there are none to prop up and maintain a family (in distress), it will fall at the stroke of the axe of misfortune.

Verse: சுழன்றும்ஏர்ப்	பின்னது	உலகம்	அதனால்			உழந்தும்	உழவே	தலை.
Translation: Translation :Howe'er they roam, the world must follow still the plougher's team; Though toilsome, culture of the ground as noblest toil esteem.
Explanation: Explanation :Agriculture, though laborious, is the most excellent (form of labour); for people, though they go about (in search of various employments), have at last to resort to the farmer.

Verse: உழுவார்	உலகத்தார்க்கு	ஆணிஅஃ	தாற்றாது			எழுவாரை	எல்லாம்	பொறுத்து.
Translation: Translation :The ploughers are the linch-pin of the world; they bear Them up who other works perform, too weak its toils to share.
Explanation: Explanation :Agriculturists are (as it were) the linch-pin of the world for they support all other workers who cannot till the soil.

Verse: உழுதுண்டு	வாழ்வாரே	வாழ்வார்மற்	றெல்லாம்			தொழுதுண்டு	பின்செல்	பவர்.
Translation: Translation :Who ploughing eat their food, they truly live: The rest to others bend subservient, eating what they give.
Explanation: Explanation :They alone live who live by agriculture; all others lead a cringing, dependent life.

Verse: பலகுடை	நீழலும்	தங்குடைக்கீழ்க்	காண்பர்			அலகுடை	நீழ	லவர்.
Translation: Translation :O'er many a land they 'll see their monarch reign, Whose fields are shaded by the waving grain.
Explanation: Explanation :Patriotic farmers desire to bring all other states under the control of their own king.

Verse: இரவார்	இரப்பார்க்கொன்று	ஈவர்	கரவாது			கைசெய்தூண்	மாலை	யவர்.
Translation: Translation :They nothing ask from others, but to askers give, Who raise with their own hands the food on which they live.
Explanation: Explanation :Those whose nature is to live by manual labour will never beg but give something to those who beg.

Verse: உழவினார்	கைம்மடங்கின்	இல்லை	விழைவதூஉம்			விட்டேம்என்	பார்க்கும்	நிலை.
Translation: Translation :For those who 've left what all men love no place is found, When they with folded hands remain who till the ground.
Explanation: Explanation :If the farmer's hands are slackened, even the ascetic state will fail.

Verse: தொடிப்புழுதி	கஃசா	உணக்கின்	பிடித்தெருவும்			வேண்டாது	சாலப்	படும்.
Translation: Translation :Reduce your soil to that dry state, When ounce is quarter-ounce's weight; Without one handful of manure, Abundant crops you thus secure.
Explanation: Explanation :If the land is dried so as to reduce one ounce of earth to a quarter, it will grow plentifully even without a handful of manure.

Verse: ஏரினும்	நன்றால்	எருவிடுதல்	கட்டபின்			நீரினும்	நன்றதன்	காப்பு.
Translation: Translation :To cast manure is better than to plough; Weed well; to guard is more than watering now
Explanation: Explanation :Manuring is better than ploughing; after weeding, watching is better than watering (it).

Verse: செல்லான்	கிழவன்	இருப்பின்	நிலம்புலந்து			இல்லாளின்	ஊடி	விடும்.
Translation: Translation :When master from the field aloof hath stood; Then land will sulk, like wife in angry mood.
Explanation: Explanation :If the owner does not (personally) attend to his cultivation, his land will behave like an angry wife and yield him no pleasure.

Verse: இலமென்று	அசைஇ	இருப்பாரைக்	காணின்			நிலமென்னும்	நல்லாள்	நகும்.
Translation: Translation :The earth, that kindly dame, will laugh to see, Men seated idle pleading poverty.
Explanation: Explanation :The maiden, Earth, will laugh at the sight of those who plead poverty and lead an idle life.

Verse: இன்மையின்	இன்னாதது	யாதெனின்	இன்மையின்			இன்மையே	இன்னா	தது.
Translation: Translation :You ask what sharper pain than poverty is known; Nothing pains more than poverty, save poverty alone.
Explanation: Explanation :There is nothing that afflicts (one) like poverty.

Verse: இன்மை	எனவொரு	பாவி	மறுமையும்			இம்மையும்	இன்றி	வரும்.
Translation: Translation :Malefactor matchless! poverty destroys This world's and the next world's joys.
Explanation: Explanation :When cruel poverty comes on, it deprives one of both the present and future (bliss).

Verse: தொல்வரவும்	தோலும்	கெடுக்கும்	தொகையாக			நல்குரவு	என்னும்	நசை.
Translation: Translation :Importunate desire, which poverty men name, Destroys both old descent and goodly fame.
Explanation: Explanation :Hankering poverty destroys at once the greatness of (one's) ancient descent and (the dignity of one's) speech.

Verse: இற்பிறந்தார்	கண்ணேயும்	இன்மை	இளிவந்த			சொற்பிறக்கும்	சோர்வு	தரும்.
Translation: Translation :From penury will spring, 'mid even those of noble race, Oblivion that gives birth to words that bring disgrace.
Explanation: Explanation :Even in those of high birth, poverty will produce the fault of uttering mean words.

Verse: நல்குரவு	என்னும்	இடும்பையுள்	பல்குரைத்			துன்பங்கள்	சென்று	படும்.
Translation: Translation :From poverty, that grievous woe, Attendant sorrows plenteous grow.
Explanation: Explanation :The misery of poverty brings in its train many (more) miseries.

Verse: நற்பொருள்	நன்குணர்ந்து	சொல்லினும்	நல்கூர்ந்தார்			சொற்பொருள்	சோர்வு	படும்.
Translation: Translation :Though deepest sense, well understood, the poor man's words convey, Their sense from memory of mankind will fade away.
Explanation: Explanation :The words of the poor are profitless, though they may be sound in thought and clear in expression.

Verse: அறஞ்சாரா	நல்குரவு	ஈன்றதா	யானும்			பிறன்போல	நோக்கப்	படும்.
Translation: Translation :From indigence devoid of virtue's grace, The mother e'en that bare, estranged, will turn her face.
Explanation: Explanation :He that is reduced to absolute poverty will be regarded as a stranger even by his own mother.

Verse: இன்றும்	வருவது	கொல்லோ	நெருநலும்			கொன்றது	போலும்	நிரப்பு.
Translation: Translation :And will it come today as yesterday, The grief of want that eats my soul away?
Explanation: Explanation :Is the poverty that almost killed me yesterday, to meet me today too ?

Verse: நெருப்பினுள்	துஞ்சலும்	ஆகும்	நிரப்பினுள்			யாதொன்றும்	கண்பாடு	அரிது.
Translation: Translation :Amid the flames sleep may men's eyelids close, In poverty the eye knows no repose.
Explanation: Explanation :One may sleep in the midst of fire; but by no means in the midst of poverty.

Verse: துப்புர	வில்லார்	துவரத்	துறவாமை			உப்பிற்கும்	காடிக்கும்	கூற்று.
Translation: Translation :Unless the destitute will utterly themselves deny, They cause their neighbour's salt and vinegar to die.
Explanation: Explanation :The destitute poor, who do not renounce their bodies, only consume their neighbour's salt and water.

Verse: இரக்க	இரத்தக்கார்க்	காணின்	கரப்பின்			அவர்பழி	தம்பழி	அன்று.
Translation: Translation :When those you find from whom 'tis meet to ask,- for aid apply; Theirs is the sin, not yours, if they the gift deny.
Explanation: Explanation :If you meet with those that may be begged of, you may beg; (but) if they withhold (their gift) it is their blame and not yours.

Verse: இன்பம்	ஒருவற்கு	இரத்தல்	இரந்தவை			துன்பம்	உறாஅ	வரின்.
Translation: Translation :Even to ask an alms may pleasure give, If what you ask without annoyance you receive.
Explanation: Explanation :Even begging may be pleasant, if what is begged for is obtained without grief (to him that begs).

Verse: கரப்பிலா	நெஞ்சின்	கடனறிவார்	முன்நின்று			இரப்புமோ	ரேஎர்	உடைத்து.
Translation: Translation :The men who nought deny, but know what's due, before their face To stand as suppliants affords especial grace.
Explanation: Explanation :There is even a beauty in standing before and begging of those who are liberal in their gifts and understand their duty (to beggars).

Verse: இரத்தலும்	ஈதலே	போலும்	கரத்தல்			கனவிலும்	தேற்றாதார்	மாட்டு.
Translation: Translation :Like giving alms, may even asking pleasant seem, From men who of denial never even dream.
Explanation: Explanation :To beg of such as never think of withholding (their charity) even in their dreams, is in fact the same as giving (it oneself);

Verse: கரப்பிலார்	வையகத்து	உண்மையால்	கண்ணின்று			இரப்பவர்	மேற்கொள்	வது.
Translation: Translation :Because on earth the men exist, who never say them nay, Men bear to stand before their eyes for help to pray.
Explanation: Explanation :As there are in the world those that give without refusing, there are (also) those that prefer to beg by simply standing before them.

Verse: கரப்பிடும்பை	யில்லாரைக்	காணின்	நிரப்பிடும்பை			எல்லாம்	ஒருங்கு	கெடும்.
Translation: Translation :It those you find from evil of 'denial' free, At once all plague of poverty will flee.
Explanation: Explanation :All the evil of begging will be removed at the sight of those who are far from the evil of refusing.

Verse: இகழ்ந்தெள்ளாது	ஈவாரைக்	காணின்	மகிழ்ந்துள்ளம்			உள்ளுள்	உவப்பது	உடைத்து.
Translation: Translation :If men are found who give and no harsh words of scorn employ, The minds of askers, through and through, will thrill with joy.
Explanation: Explanation :Beggars rejoice exceedingly when they behold those who bestow (their alms) with kindness and courtesy.

Verse: இரப்பாரை	இல்லாயின்	ஈர்ங்கண்மா	ஞாலம்			மரப்பாவை	சென்றுவந்	தற்று.
Translation: Translation :If askers cease, the mighty earth, where cooling fountains flow, Will be a stage where wooden puppets come and go.
Explanation: Explanation :If there were no beggars, (the actions done in) the cool wide world would only resemble the movement of a puppet.

Verse: ஈவார்கண்	என்னுண்டாம்	தோற்றம்	இரந்துகோள்			மேவார்	இலாஅக்	கடை.
Translation: Translation :What glory will there be to men of generous soul, When none are found to love the askers' role?
Explanation: Explanation :What (praise) would there be to givers (of alms) if there were no beggars to ask for and reveive (them).

Verse: இரப்பான்	வெகுளாமை	வேண்டும்	நிரப்பிடும்பை			தானேயும்	சாலும்	கரி.
Translation: Translation :Askers refused from wrath must stand aloof; The plague of poverty itself is ample proof.
Explanation: Explanation :He who begs ought not to be angry (at a refusal); for even the misery of (his own) poverty should be a sufficient reason (for so doing).

Verse: கரவாது	உவந்தீயும்	கண்ணன்னார்	கண்ணும்			இரவாமை	கோடி	உறும்.
Translation: Translation :Ten million-fold 'tis greater gain, asking no alms to live, Even from those, like eyes in worth, who nought concealing gladly give.
Explanation: Explanation :Not to beg (at all) even from those excellent persons who cheerfully give without refusing, will do immense good.

Verse: இரந்தும்	உயிர்வாழ்தல்	வேண்டின்	பரந்து			கெடுக	உலகியற்றி	யான்.
Translation: Translation :If he that shaped the world desires that men should begging go, Through life's long course, let him a wanderer be and perish so.
Explanation: Explanation :If the Creator of the world has decreed even begging as a means of livelihood, may he too go abegging and perish.

Verse: இன்மை	இடும்பை	இரந்துதீர்	வாமென்னும்			வன்மையின்	வன்பாட்ட	தில்.
Translation: Translation :Nothing is harder than the hardness that will say, 'The plague of penury by asking alms we'll drive away.'
Explanation: Explanation :There is no greater folly than the boldness with which one seeks to remedy the evils of poverty by begging (rather than by working).

Verse: இடமெல்லாம்	கொள்ளாத்	தகைத்தே	இடமில்லாக்			காலும்	இரவொல்லாச்	சால்பு.
Translation: Translation :Who ne'er consent to beg in utmost need, their worth Has excellence of greatness that transcends the earth.
Explanation: Explanation :Even the whole world cannot sufficiently praise the dignity that would not beg even in the midst of destitution.

Verse: தெண்ணீர்	அடுபுற்கை	ஆயினும்	தாள்தந்தது			உண்ணலின்	ஊங்கினிய	தில்.
Translation: Translation :Nothing is sweeter than to taste the toil-won cheer, Though mess of pottage as tasteless as the water clear.
Explanation: Explanation :Even thin gruel is ambrosia to him who has obtained it by labour.

Verse: ஆவிற்கு	நீரென்று	இரப்பினும்	நாவிற்கு			இரவின்	இளிவந்த	தில்.
Translation: Translation :E'en if a draught of water for a cow you ask, Nought's so distasteful to the tongue as beggar's task.
Explanation: Explanation :There is nothing more disgraceful to one's tongue than to use it in begging water even for a cow.

Verse: இரப்பன்	இரப்பாரை	எல்லாம்	இரப்பின்			கரப்பார்	இரவன்மின்	என்று.
Translation: Translation :One thing I beg of beggars all, 'If beg ye may, Of those who hide their wealth, beg not, I pray.'
Explanation: Explanation :I beseech all beggars and say, "If you need to beg, never beg of those who give unwillingly."

Verse: இரவென்னும்	ஏமாப்பில்	தோணி	கரவென்னும்			பார்தாக்கப்	பக்கு	விடும்.
Translation: Translation :The fragile bark of beggary Wrecked on denial's rock will lie.
Explanation: Explanation :The unsafe raft of begging will split when it strikes on the rock of refusal.

Verse: இரவுள்ள	உள்ளம்	உருகும்	கரவுள்ள			உள்ளதூஉம்	இன்றிக்	கெடும்.
Translation: Translation :The heart will melt away at thought of beggary, With thought of stern repulse 'twill perish utterly.
Explanation: Explanation :To think of (the evil of) begging is enough to melt one's heart; but to think of refusal is enough to break it.

Verse: கரப்பவர்க்கு	யாங்கொளிக்கும்	கொல்லோ	இரப்பவர்			சொல்லாடப்	போஒம்	உயிர்.
Translation: Translation :E'en as he asks, the shamefaced asker dies; Where shall his spirit hide who help denies?
Explanation: Explanation :Saying "No" to a beggar takes away his life. (but as that very word will kill the refuser) where then would the latter's life hide itself ?

Verse: மக்களே	போல்வர்	கயவர்	அவரன்ன			ஒப்பாரி	யாங்கண்ட	தில்.
Translation: Translation :The base resemble men in outward form, I ween; But counterpart exact to them I've never seen.
Explanation: Explanation :The base resemble men perfectly (as regards form); and we have not seen such (exact) resemblance (among any other species).

Verse: நன்றறி	வாரிற்	கயவர்	திருவுடையர்			நெஞ்சத்து	அவலம்	இலர்.
Translation: Translation :Than those of grateful heart the base must luckier be, Their minds from every anxious thought are free!
Explanation: Explanation :The low enjoy more felicity than those who know what is good; for the former are not troubled with anxiety (as to the good).

Verse: தேவர்	அனையர்	கயவர்	அவருந்தாம்			மேவன	செய்தொழுக	லான்.
Translation: Translation :The base are as the Gods; they too Do ever what they list to do!
Explanation: Explanation :The base resemble the Gods; for the base act as they like.

Verse: அகப்பட்டி	ஆவாரைக்	காணின்	அவர஧ன்			மிகப்பட்டுச்	செம்மாக்கும்	கீழ்.
Translation: Translation :When base men those behold of conduct vile, They straight surpass them, and exulting smile.
Explanation: Explanation :The base feels proud when he sees persons whose acts meaner than his own.

Verse: அச்சமே	கீழ்களது	ஆசாரம்	எச்சம்			அவாவுண்டேல்	உண்டாம்	சிறிது.
Translation: Translation :Fear is the base man's virtue; if that fail, Intense desire some little may avail.
Explanation: Explanation :(The principle of) behaviour in the mean is chiefly fear; if not, hope of gain, to some extent.

Verse: அறைபறை	அன்னர்	கயவர்தாம்	கேட்ட			மறைபிறர்க்கு	உய்த்துரைக்க	லான்.
Translation: Translation :The base are like the beaten drum; for, when they hear The sound the secret out in every neighbour's ear.
Explanation: Explanation :The base are like a drum that is beaten, for they unburden to others the secrets they have heard.

Verse: ஈர்ங்கை	விதிரார்	கயவர்	கொடிறுடைக்கும்			கூன்கையர்	அல்லா	தவர்க்கு.
Translation: Translation :From off their moistened hands no clinging grain they shake, Unless to those with clenched fist their jaws who break.
Explanation: Explanation :The mean will not (even) shake off (what sticks to) their hands (soon after a meal) to any but those who would break their jaws with their clenched fists.

Verse: சொல்லப்	பயன்படுவர்	சான்றோர்	கரும்புபோல்			கொல்லப்	பயன்படும்	கீழ்.
Translation: Translation :The good to those will profit yield fair words who use; The base, like sugar-cane, will profit those who bruise.
Explanation: Explanation :The great bestow (their alms) as soon as they are informed; (but) the mean, like the sugar-cane, only when they are tortured to death.

Verse: உடுப்பதூஉம்	உண்பதூஉம்	காணின்	பிறர்மேல்			வடுக்காண	வற்றாகும்	கீழ்.
Translation: Translation :If neighbours clothed and fed he see, the base Is mighty man some hidden fault to trace?
Explanation: Explanation :The base will bring an evil (accusation) against others, as soon as he sees them (enjoying) good food and clothing.

Verse: எற்றிற்	குரியர்	கயவரொன்று	உற்றக்கால்			விற்றற்கு	உரியர்	விரைந்து.
Translation: Translation :For what is base man fit, if griefs assail? Himself to offer, there and then, for sale!
Explanation: Explanation :The base will hasten to sell themselves as soon as a calamity has befallen them. For what else are they fitted ?

Verse: அணங்குகொல்	ஆய்மயில்	கொல்லோ	கனங்குழை			மாதர்கொல்	மாலும்என்	நெஞ்சு.
Translation: Translation :Goddess? or peafowl rare? She whose ears rich jewels wear, Is she a maid of human kind? All wildered is my mind!
Explanation: Explanation :Is this jewelled female a celestial, a choice peahen, or a human being ? My mind is perplexed.

Verse: நோக்கினாள்	நோக்கெதிர்	நோக்குதல்	தாக்கணங்கு			தானைக்கொண்	டன்ன	துடைத்து.
Translation: Translation :She of the beaming eyes, To my rash look her glance replies, As if the matchless goddess' hand Led forth an armed band.
Explanation: Explanation :This female beauty returning my looks is like a celestial maiden coming with an army to contend against me.

Verse: பண்டறியேன்	கூற்றென்	பதனை	இனியறிந்தேன்			பெண்டகையால்	பேரமர்க்	கட்டு.
Translation: Translation :Death's form I formerly Knew not; but now 'tis plain to me; He comes in lovely maiden's guise, With soul-subduing eyes.
Explanation: Explanation :I never knew before what is called Yama; I see it now; it is the eyes that carry on a great fight with (the help of) female qualities.

Verse: கண்டார்	உயிருண்ணும்	தோற்றத்தால்	பெண்டகைப்			பேதைக்கு	அமர்த்தன	கண்.
Translation: Translation :In sweet simplicity, A woman's gracious form hath she; But yet those eyes, that drink my life, Are with the form at strife!
Explanation: Explanation :These eyes that seem to kill those who look at them are as it were in hostilities with this feminine simplicity.

Verse: கூற்றமோ	கண்ணோ	பிணையோ	மடவரல்			நோக்கமிம்	மூன்றும்	உடைத்து.
Translation: Translation :The light that on me gleams, Is it death's dart? or eye's bright beams? Or fawn's shy glance? All three appear In form of maiden here.
Explanation: Explanation :Is it Yama, (a pair of) eyes or a hind ?- Are not all these three in the looks of this maid ?

Verse: கொடும்புருவம்	கோடா	மறைப்பின்	நடுங்கஞர்			செய்யல	மன்இவள்	கண்.
Translation: Translation :If cruel eye-brow's bow, Unbent, would veil those glances now; The shafts that wound this trembling heart Her eyes no more would dart.
Explanation: Explanation :Her eyes will cause (me) no trembling sorrow, if they are properly hidden by her cruel arched eye-brows.

Verse: கடாஅக்	களிற்றின்மேற்	கட்படாம்	மாதர்			படாஅ	முலைமேல்	துகில்.
Translation: Translation :As veil o'er angry eyes Of raging elephant that lies, The silken cincture's folds invest This maiden's panting breast.
Explanation: Explanation :The cloth that covers the firm bosom of this maiden is (like) that which covers the eyes of a rutting elephant.

Verse: ஒண்ணுதற்	கோஒ	உடைந்ததே	ஞாட்பினுள்			நண்ணாரும்	உட்குமென்	பீடு.
Translation: Translation :Ah! woe is me! my might, That awed my foemen in the fight, By lustre of that beaming brow Borne down, lies broken now!
Explanation: Explanation :On her bright brow alone is destroyed even that power of mine that used to terrify the most fearless foes in the battlefield.

Verse: பிணையேர்	மடநோக்கும்	நாணும்	உடையாட்கு			அணியெவனோ	ஏதில	தந்து.
Translation: Translation :Like tender fawn's her eye; Clothed on is she with modesty; What added beauty can be lent; By alien ornament?
Explanation: Explanation :Of what use are other jewels to her who is adorned with modesty, and the meek looks of a hind ?

Verse: உண்டார்கண்	அல்லது	அடுநறாக்	காமம்போல்			கண்டார்	மகிழ்செய்தல்	இன்று.
Translation: Translation :The palm-tree's fragrant wine, To those who taste yields joys divine; But love hath rare felicity For those that only see!
Explanation: Explanation :Unlike boiled honey which yields delight only when it is drunk, love gives pleasure even when looked at.

Verse: இருநோக்கு	இவளுண்கண்	உள்ளது	ஒருநோக்கு			நோய்நோக்கொன்	றந்நோய்	மருந்து.
Translation: Translation :A double witchery have glances of her liquid eye; One glance is glance that brings me pain; the other heals again.
Explanation: Explanation :There are two looks in the dyed eyes of this (fair one); one causes pain, and the other is the cure thereof.

Verse: கண்களவு	கொள்ளும்	சிறுநோக்கம்	காமத்தில்			செம்பாகம்	அன்று	பெரிது.
Translation: Translation :The furtive glance, that gleams one instant bright, Is more than half of love's supreme delight.
Explanation: Explanation :A single stolen glance of her eyes is more than half the pleasure (of sexual embrace).

Verse: நோக்கினாள்	நோக்கி	இறைஞ்சினாள்	அஃதவள்			யாப்பினுள்	அட்டிய	நீர்.
Translation: Translation :She looked, and looking drooped her head: On springing shoot of love 'its water shed!
Explanation: Explanation :She has looked (at men) and stooped (her head); and that (sign) waters as it were (the corn of) our love.

Verse: யான்நோக்கும்	காலை	நிலன்நோக்கும்	நோக்காக்கால்			தான்நோக்கி	மெல்ல	நகும்.
Translation: Translation :I look on her: her eyes are on the ground the while: I look away: she looks on me with timid smile.
Explanation: Explanation :When I look, she looks down; when I do not, she looks and smiles gently.

Verse: குறிக்கொண்டு	நோக்காமை	அல்லால்	ஒருகண்			சிறக்கணித்தாள்	போல	நகும்
Translation: Translation :She seemed to see me not; but yet the maid Her love, by smiling side-long glance, betrayed.
Explanation: Explanation :She not only avoids a direct look at me, but looks as it were with a half-closed eye and smiles.

Verse: உறாஅ	தவர்போல்	சொலினும்	செறாஅர்சொல்			ஒல்லை	உணரப்	படும்.
Translation: Translation :Though with their lips affection they disown, Yet, when they hate us not, 'tis quickly known.
Explanation: Explanation :Though they may speak harshly as if they were strangers, the words of the friendly are soon understood.

Verse: செறாஅச்	சிறுசொல்லும்	செற்றார்போல்	நோக்கும்			உறாஅர்போன்று	உற்றார்	குறிப்பு.
Translation: Translation :The slighting words that anger feign, while eyes their love reveal. Are signs of those that love, but would their love conceal.
Explanation: Explanation :Little words that are harsh and looks that are hateful are (but) the expressions of lovers who wish to act like strangers.

Verse: அசையியற்கு	உண்டாண்டோர்	ஏஎர்யான்	நோக்கப்			பசையினள்	பைய	நகும்.
Translation: Translation :I gaze, the tender maid relents the while; And, oh the matchless grace of that soft smile!
Explanation: Explanation :When I look, the pitying maid looks in return and smiles gently; and that is a comforting sign for me.

Verse: ஏதிலார்	போலப்	பொதுநோக்கு	நோக்குதல்			காதலார்	கண்ணே	உள.
Translation: Translation :The look indifferent, that would its love disguise, Is only read aright by lovers' eyes.
Explanation: Explanation :Both the lovers are capable of looking at each other in an ordinary way, as if they were perfect strangers.

Verse: கண்ணொடு	கண்இணை	நோக்கொக்கின்	வாய்ச்சொற்கள்			என்ன	பயனும்	இல.
Translation: Translation :When eye to answering eye reveals the tale of love, All words that lips can say must useless prove.
Explanation: Explanation :The words of the mouths are of no use whatever, when there is perfect agreement between the eyes (of lovers).

Verse: கண்டுகேட்டு	உண்டுயிர்த்து	உற்றறியும்	ஐம்புலனும்			ஒண்தொடி	கண்ணே	உள.
Translation: Translation :All joys that senses five- sight, hearing, taste, smell, touch- can give, In this resplendent armlets-bearing damsel live!
Explanation: Explanation :The (simultaneous) enjoyment of the five senses of sight, hearing, taste, smell and touch can only be found with bright braceleted (women).

Verse: பிணிக்கு	மருந்து	பிறமன்	அணியிழை			தன்நோய்க்குத்	தானே	மருந்து.
Translation: Translation :Disease and medicine antagonists we surely see; This maid, to pain she gives, herself is remedy.
Explanation: Explanation :The remedy for a disease is always something different (from it); but for the disease caused by this jewelled maid, she is herself the cure.

Verse: தாம்வீழ்வார்	மென்றோள்	துயிலின்	இனிதுகொல்			தாமரைக்	கண்ணான்	உலகு.
Translation: Translation :Than rest in her soft arms to whom the soul is giv'n, Is any sweeter joy in his, the Lotus-eyed-one's heaven?
Explanation: Explanation :Can the lotus-eyed Vishnu's heaven be indeed as sweet to those who delight to sleep in the delicate arms of their beloved ?

Verse: நீங்கின்	தெறூஉம்	குறுகுங்கால்	தண்ணென்னும்			தீயாண்டுப்	பெற்றாள்	இவள்.
Translation: Translation :Withdraw, it burns; approach, it soothes the pain; Whence did the maid this wondrous fire obtain?
Explanation: Explanation :From whence has she got this fire that burns when I withdraw and cools when I approach ?

Verse: வேட்	ட	பொழுதின்	அவையவை			போலுமே	தோட்	டார்	கதுப்பினாள்			தோள்.
Translation: Translation :In her embrace, whose locks with flowery wreaths are bound, Each varied form of joy the soul can wish is found.
Explanation: Explanation :The shoulders of her whose locks are adorned with flowers delight me as if they were the very sweets I have desired (to get).

Verse: உறுதோறு	உயிர்தளிர்ப்பத்	தீண்டலால்	பேதைக்கு			அமிழ்தின்	இயன்றன	தோள்.
Translation: Translation :Ambrosia are the simple maiden's arms; when I attain Their touch, my withered life puts forth its buds again!
Explanation: Explanation :The shoulders of this fair one are made of ambrosia, for they revive me with pleasure every time I embrace them.

Verse: தம்மில்	இருந்து	தமதுபாத்து	உண்டற்றால்			அம்மா	அரிவை	முயக்கு.
Translation: Translation :As when one eats from household store, with kindly grace Sharing his meal: such is this golden maid's embrace.
Explanation: Explanation :The embraces of a gold-complexioned beautiful female are as pleasant as to dwell in one's own house and live by one's own (earnings) after distributing (a portion of it in charity).

Verse: வீழும்	இருவர்க்கு	இனிதே	வளியிடை			போழப்	படாஅ	முயக்கு.
Translation: Translation :Sweet is the strict embrace of those whom fond affection binds, Where no dissevering breath of discord entrance finds.
Explanation: Explanation :To ardent lovers sweet is the embrace that cannot be penetrated even by a breath of breeze.

Verse: ஊடல்	உணர்தல்	புணர்தல்	இவைகாமம்			கூடியார்	பெற்ற	பயன்.
Translation: Translation :The jealous variance, the healing of the strife, reunion gained: These are the fruits from wedded love obtained.
Explanation: Explanation :Love quarrel, reconciliation and intercourse - these are the advantages reaped by those who marry for lust.

Verse: அறிதோறு	அறியாமை	கண்டற்றால்	காமம்			செறிதோறும்	சேயிழை	மாட்டு.
Translation: Translation :The more men learn, the more their lack of learning they detect; 'Tis so when I approach the maid with gleaming jewels decked.
Explanation: Explanation :As (one's) ignorance is discovered the more one learns, so does repeated intercourse with a well-adorned female (only create a desire for more).

Verse: நன்னீரை	வாழி	அனிச்சமே	நின்னினும்			மென்னீரள்	யாம்வீழ்	பவள்.
Translation: Translation :O flower of the sensitive plant! than thee More tender's the maiden beloved by me.
Explanation: Explanation :May you flourish, O Anicham! you have a delicate nature. But my beloved is more delicate than you.

Verse: மலர்காணின்	மையாத்தி	நெஞ்சே	இவள்கண்			பலர்காணும்	பூவொக்கும்	என்று.
Translation: Translation :You deemed, as you saw the flowers, her eyes were as flowers, my soul, That many may see; it was surely some folly that over you stole!
Explanation: Explanation :O my soul, fancying that flowers which are seen by many can resemble her eyes, you become confused at the sight of them.

Verse: முறிமேனி	முத்தம்	முறுவல்	வெறிநாற்றம்			வேலுண்கண்	வேய்த்தோ	ளவட்கு.
Translation: Translation :As tender shoot her frame; teeth, pearls; around her odours blend; Darts are the eyes of her whose shoulders like the bambu bend.
Explanation: Explanation :The complexion of this bamboo-shouldered one is that of a shoot; her teeth, are pearls; her breath, fragrance; and her dyed eyes, lances.

Verse: காணின்	குவளை	கவிழ்ந்து	நிலன்நோக்கும்			மாணிழை	கண்ணொவ்வேம்	என்று.
Translation: Translation :The lotus, seeing her, with head demiss, the ground would eye, And say, 'With eyes of her, rich gems who wears, we cannot vie.'
Explanation: Explanation :If the blue lotus could see, it would stoop and look at the ground saying, "I can never resemble the eyes of this excellent jewelled one."

Verse: அனிச்சப்பூக்	கால்களையாள்	பெய்தாள்	நுகப்பிற்கு			நல்ல	படாஅ	பறை.
Translation: Translation :The flowers of the sensitive plant as a girdle around her she placed; The stems she forgot to nip off; they 'll weigh down the delicate waist.
Explanation: Explanation :No merry drums will be beaten for the (tender) waist of her who has adorned herself with the anicham without having removed its stem.

Verse: மதியும்	மடந்தை	முகனும்	அறியா			பதியின்	கலங்கிய	மீன்.
Translation: Translation :The stars perplexed are rushing wildly from their spheres; For like another moon this maiden's face appears.
Explanation: Explanation :The stars have become confused in their places not being able to distinguish between the moon and the maid's countenance.

Verse: அறுவாய்	நிறைந்த	அவிர்மதிக்குப்	போல			மறுவுண்டோ	மாதர்	முகத்து.
Translation: Translation :In moon, that waxing waning shines, as sports appear, Are any spots discerned in face of maiden here?
Explanation: Explanation :Could there be spots in the face of this maid like those in the bright full moon ?

Verse: மாதர்	முகம்போல்	ஒளிவிட	வல்லையேல்			காதலை	வாழி	மத஧.
Translation: Translation :Farewell, O moon! If that thine orb could shine Bright as her face, thou shouldst be love of mine.
Explanation: Explanation :If you can indeed shine like the face of women, flourish, O moon, for then would you be worth loving ?

Verse: மலரன்ன	கண்ணாள்	முகமொத்தி	யாயின்			பலர்காணத்	தோன்றல்	மதி.
Translation: Translation :If as her face, whose eyes are flowers, thou wouldst have charms for me, Shine for my eyes alone, O moon, shine not for all to see!
Explanation: Explanation :O moon, if you wish to resemble the face of her whose eyes are like (these) flowers, do not appear so as to be seen by all.

Verse: அனிச்சமும்	அன்னத்தின்	தூவியும்	மாதர்			அடிக்கு	நெருஞ்சிப்	பழம்.
Translation: Translation :The flower of the sensitive plant, and the down on the swan's white breast, As the thorn are harsh, by the delicate feet of this maiden pressed.
Explanation: Explanation :The anicham and the feathers of the swan are to the feet of females, like the fruit of the (thorny) Nerunji.

Verse: பாலொடு	தேன்கலந்	தற்றே	பணிமொழி			வாலெயிறு	ஊறிய	நீர்.
Translation: Translation :The dew on her white teeth, whose voice is soft and low, Is as when milk and honey mingled flow.
Explanation: Explanation :The water which oozes from the white teeth of this soft speeched damsel is like a mixture of milk and honey.

Verse: உடம்பொடு	உயிரிடை	என்னமற்	றன்ன			மடந்தையொடு	எம்மிடை	நட்பு.
Translation: Translation :Between this maid and me the friendship kind Is as the bonds that soul and body bind.
Explanation: Explanation :The love between me and this damsel is like the union of body and soul.

Verse: கருமணியிற்	பாவாய்நீ	போதாயாம்	வீழும்			திருநுதற்கு	இல்லை	இடம்.
Translation: Translation :For her with beauteous brow, the maid I love, there place is none; To give her image room, O pupil of mine eye, begone!
Explanation: Explanation :O you image in the pupil (of my eye)! depart; there is no room for (my) fair-browed beloved.

Verse: வாழ்தல்	உயிர்க்கன்னள்	ஆயிழை	சாதல்			அதற்கன்னள்	நீங்கும்	இடத்து.
Translation: Translation :Life is she to my very soul when she draws nigh; Dissevered from the maid with jewels rare, I die!
Explanation: Explanation :My fair-jewelled one resembles the living soul (when she is in union with me), the dying soul when she leaves me.

Verse: உள்ளுவன்	மன்யான்	மறப்பின்	மறப்பறியேன்			ஒள்ளமர்க்	கண்ணாள்	குணம்.
Translation: Translation :I might recall, if I could once forget; but from my heart Her charms fade not, whose eyes gleam like the warrior's dart.
Explanation: Explanation :If I had forgotten her who has bright battling eyes, I would have remembered (thee); but I never forget her. (Thus says he to her maid).

Verse: கண்ணுள்ளின்	போகார்	இமைப்பின்	பருகுவரா			நுண்ணியர்எம்	காத	லவர்.
Translation: Translation :My loved one's subtle form departs not from my eyes; I wink them not, lest I should pain him where he lies.
Explanation: Explanation :My lover would not depart from mine eyes; even if I wink, he would not suffer (from pain); he is so ethereal.

Verse: கண்ணுள்ளார்	காத	லவராகக்	கண்ணும்			எழுதேம்	கரப்பாக்கு	அறிந்து.
Translation: Translation :My love doth ever in my eyes reside; I stain them not, fearing his form to hide.
Explanation: Explanation :As my lover abides in my eyes, I will not even paint them, for he would (then) have to conceal himself.

Verse: நெஞ்சத்தார்	காத	லவராக	வெய்துண்டல்			அஞ்சுதும்	வேபாக்	கறிந்து.
Translation: Translation :Within my heart my lover dwells; from food I turn That smacks of heat, lest he should feel it burn.
Explanation: Explanation :As my lover is in my heart, I am afraid of eating (anything) hot, for I know it would pain him.

Verse: இமைப்பின்	கரப்பாக்கு	அறிவல்	அனைத்திற்கே			ஏதிலர்	என்னும்இவ்	வூர்.
Translation: Translation :I fear his form to hide, nor close my eyes: 'Her love estranged is gone!' the village cries.
Explanation: Explanation :I will not wink, knowing that if I did, my lover would hide himself; and for this reason, this town says, he is unloving.

Verse: உவந்துறைவர்	உள்ளத்துள்	என்றும்	இகந்துறைவர்			ஏதிலர்	என்னும்இவ்	வூர்.
Translation: Translation :Rejoicing in my very soul he ever lies; 'Her love estranged is gone far off!' the village cries.
Explanation: Explanation :My lover dwells in my heart with perpetual delight; but the town says he is unloving and (therefore) dwells afar.

Verse: காமம்	உழந்து	வருந்தினார்க்கு	ஏமம்			மடலல்லது	இல்லை	வலி.
Translation: Translation :To those who 've proved love's joy, and now afflicted mourn, Except the helpful 'horse of palm', no other strength remains.
Explanation: Explanation :To those who after enjoyment of sexual pleasure suffer (for want of more), there is no help so efficient as the palmyra horse.

Verse: நோனா	உடம்பும்	உயிரும்	மடலேறும்			நாணினை	நீக்கி	நிறுத்து.
Translation: Translation :My body and my soul, that can no more endure, Will lay reserve aside, and mount the 'horse of palm'.
Explanation: Explanation :Having got rid of shame, the suffering body and soul save themselves on the palmyra horse.

Verse: நாணொடு	நல்லாண்மை	பண்டுடையேன்	இன்றுடையேன்			காமுற்றார்	ஏறும்	மடல்.
Translation: Translation :I once retained reserve and seemly manliness; To-day I nought possess but lovers' 'horse of palm'.
Explanation: Explanation :Modesty and manliness were once my own; now, my own is the palmyra horse that is ridden by the lustful.

Verse: காமக்	கடும்புனல்	உய்க்கும்	நாணொடு			நல்லாண்மை	என்னும்	புணை.
Translation: Translation :Love's rushing tide will sweep away the raft Of seemly manliness and shame combined.
Explanation: Explanation :The raft of modesty and manliness, is, alas, carried-off by the strong current of lust.

Verse: தொடலைக்	குறுந்தொடி	தந்தாள்	மடலொடு			மாலை	உழக்கும்	துயர்.
Translation: Translation :The maid that slender armlets wears, like flowers entwined, Has brought me 'horse of palm,' and pangs of eventide!
Explanation: Explanation :She with the small garland-like bracelets has given me the palmyra horse and the sorrow that is endured at night.

Verse: மடலூர்தல்	யாமத்தும்	உள்ளுவேன்	மன்ற			படல்ஒல்லா	பேதைக்கென்	கண்.
Translation: Translation :Of climbing 'horse of palm' in midnight hour, I think; My eyes know no repose for that same simple maid.
Explanation: Explanation :Mine eyes will not close in sleep on your mistress's account; even at midnight will I think of mounting the palmyra horse.

Verse: கடலன்ன	காமம்	உழந்தும்	மடலேறாப்			பெண்ணின்	பெருந்தக்க	தில்.
Translation: Translation :There's nought of greater worth than woman's long-enduring soul, Who, vexed by love like ocean waves, climbs not the 'horse of palm'.
Explanation: Explanation :There is nothing so noble as the womanly nature that would not ride the palmyra horse, though plunged a sea of lust.

Verse: நிறையரியர்	மன்அளியர்	என்னாது	காமம்			மறையிறந்து	மன்று	படும்.
Translation: Translation :In virtue hard to move, yet very tender, too, are we; Love deems not so, would rend the veil, and court publicity!
Explanation: Explanation :Even the Lust (of women) transgresses its secrecy and appears in public, forgetting that they are too chaste and liberal (to be overcome by it).

Verse: அறிகிலார்	எல்லாரும்	என்றேஎன்	காமம்			மறுகின்	மறுகும்	மருண்டு.
Translation: Translation :'There's no one knows my heart,' so says my love, And thus, in public ways, perturbed will rove.
Explanation: Explanation :My lust, feeling that it is not known by all, reels confused in the streets (of this town).

Verse: யாம்கண்ணின்	காண	நகுப	அறிவில்லார்			யாம்பட்ட	தாம்படா	ஆறு.
Translation: Translation :Before my eyes the foolish make a mock of me, Because they ne'er endured the pangs I now must drie.
Explanation: Explanation :Even strangers laugh (at us) so as to be seen by us, for they have not suffered.

Verse: அலரெழ	ஆருயிர்	ந஧ற்கும்	அதனைப்			பலரறியார்	பாக்கியத்	தால்.
Translation: Translation :By this same rumour's rise, my precious life stands fast; Good fortune grant the many know this not!
Explanation: Explanation :My precious life is saved by the raise of rumour, and this, to my good luck no others are aware of.

Verse: மலரன்ன	கண்ணாள்	அருமை	அறியாது			அலரெமக்கு	ஈந்ததிவ்	வூர்.
Translation: Translation :The village hath to us this rumour giv'n, that makes her mine; Unweeting all the rareness of the maid with flower-like eyne.
Explanation: Explanation :Not knowing the value of her whose eyes are like flowers this town has got up a rumour about me.

Verse: உறாஅதோ	ஊரறிந்த	கெளவை	அதனைப்			பெறாஅது	பெற்றன்ன	நீர்த்து.
Translation: Translation :The rumour spread within the town, is it not gain to me? It is as though that were obtained that may not be.
Explanation: Explanation :Will I not get a rumour that is known to the (whole) town ? For what I have not got is as if I had got it (already).

Verse: கவ்வையால்	கவ்விது	காமம்	அதுவின்றேல்			தவ்வென்னும்	தன்மை	இழந்து.
Translation: Translation :The rumour rising makes my love to rise; My love would lose its power and languish otherwise.
Explanation: Explanation :Rumour increases the violence of my passion; without it it would grow weak and waste away.

Verse: களித்தொறும்	கள்ளுண்டல்	வேட்டற்றால்	காமம்			வெளிப்படுந்	தோறும்	இனிது.
Translation: Translation :The more man drinks, the more he ever drunk would be; The more my love's revealed, the sweeter 'tis to me!
Explanation: Explanation :As drinking liquor is delightful (to one) whenever one is in mirth, so is lust delightful to me whenever it is the subject of rumour.

Verse: கண்டது	மன்னும்	ஒருநாள்	அலர்மன்னும்			திங்களைப்	பாம்புகொண்	டற்று.
Translation: Translation :I saw him but one single day: rumour spreads soon As darkness, when the dragon seizes on the moon.
Explanation: Explanation :It was but a single day that I looked on (my lover); but the rumour thereof has spread like the seizure of the moon by the serpent.

Verse: ஊரவர்	கெளவை	எருவாக	அன்னைசொல்			நீராக	நீளும்இந்	நோய்.
Translation: Translation :My anguish grows apace: the town's report Manures it; my mother's word doth water it.
Explanation: Explanation :This malady (of lust) is manured by the talk of women and watered by the (harsh) words of my mother.

Verse: நெய்யால்	எரிநுதுப்பேம்	என்றற்றால்	கெளவையால்			காமம்	நுதுப்பேம்	எனல்.
